Title: The Guardian Frogs of Borneo
Subtitle: Why Exceptions Matter in Biology and Everyday Life
SponsoredBy: - [Johana Goyes Vallejos, PhD](https://jogoyesvallejos.weebly.com/) — Postdoc in the Division of Biological Sciences, University of Missouri – Columbia

overview.Text:
#### Driving Question(s):
- Across animal species, is there truth to the stereotype that males are “competitive,” while females are “caring”, or is this an oversimplification?
- Are the smooth guardian frogs of Borneo the first known species of frog with “competitive females” and “caring males”?
#### Essential Question(s):
- How can we use scientific methods to identify a general pattern?
- Why do exceptions matter in science and in life?
#### Learning Objective(s):
1. Explain how animal behavior facilitates in survival and reproduction.
2. Collect, reorganize, and analyze data to identify a pattern (that males tend to have adaptations to compete for mates, while females provide more parental care), and interpret exceptions to that pattern.
3. Understand that biological data are variable.
4. Learn to test hypotheses by interpreting authentic scientific graphs and data.
5. Cite evidence to support explanatory claims.
6. Integrate multiple lines of evidence to explain why biological exceptions matter to science and society.

#### Hooks
- Part 1: Highly interactive card-based activity that simulates data collection + amazing animal videos
- Part 2: Atmospheric videos of Borneo, first person narrative of an early career Latina scientist + use of authentic data
overview.Description:
This lesson puts students in the role of scientists, collecting and analyzing real data to answer questions. In Part 1, students "collect" data through a card-based activity called "Role With It." Briefly, students get a male or female card of 1 out of 12 species. When their card is called, students introduce it with a "song" and dance that match the attributes of the species it represents. The class then records data on sexual signal exaggeration and parental investment for that species. 

Once they have collected all 24 specimens (cards) students analyze this data (for Part 2) to generate a general observation: "across nonhuman animal species, females tend to be more caring (contributing more parental investment), while males tend to be more adapted to attracting and competing for mates. These are known as *conventional sex roles.* Students then identify *sex-role-reversed species,* such as jacanas (a bird) and guardian frogs, which have "caring" males and "competitive" females.

Part 3 dives into fascinating geography, videos from the field, and real data to test whether the Smooth Guardian Frog (*Limnonectes palavenensis*) is truly the first known sex-role-reversed frog species, with caring males and competitive females. The lesson begins with an atmospheric video that immerses students in the sights, sounds, and mysteries of the island of Borneo. Students are then given a brief introduction to the geography of the region and learn that Borneo is claimed by three Asian countries (Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei). The rest of the lesson focuses on Dr. Johana Goyes Vallejos' research in the forests of Brunei. Students analyze her actual data to test hypotheses by synthesizing information and analyzing a scatter plot to determine that this fascinating species is indeed the first frog known to have "caring males" and "competitive females." 

The lesson offers a wide variety of opportunities for student movement, collaboration, creativity, and active engagement.

Multimedia.title: Do Female Frogs Call?
Multimedia.description: Dr. Johana Goyes-Vallejos discovers that in the smooth guardian frog of Borneo, female frogs call. In frog species, typically male frogs call, while females stay silent. Dr. Johana Goyes-Vallejos shows that in the smooth guardian frog of Borneo (Limnonectes palavanensis) this is not the case and that female frogs call, too, producing spontaneous vocalizations to attract males. Dr. Goyes-Vallejos’ discovery that female frogs call suggests that L. palavanensis exhibits a reversal in calling behavior and possibly a sex-role-reversed mating system, which would be the first ever observed in a frog species.
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: For Part 2: We show parts of this video to introduce students to Dr. Goyes-Vallejos and her research. They will then analyze some of her data.

Data.lessonPreface: There is a single worksheet packet for Parts 1 & 2. Part 1 (Data collection) will likely take a full class period. Part 2 (Analysis) can be done in another class period or independently. Students should be able to complete Part 3 in 1 class period.

parts.partPreface: Students "collect" data in a fun activity blending creative movement, cards, animal videos, and data literacy. Don't be intimidated by the length of the presentation–you will zip through the slides! In Part 2, students will analyze this data.

steps.StepTitle: In animals, which sex is strong, caring, competitive, or protective?
steps.StepQuickDescription: A quick activity to get students thinking about the behavioral roles that males and females play across the animal kingdom.
steps.StepDetails:
Students will pick one of the supplied adjectives and categorize it to one of the sexes, and provide an example of a nonhuman animal that demonstrates this adjective. The idea is to have students think about their preconceptions about *sex roles*. We define it here, but won't introduce the term until part 2. A reason for this is that the utility of the term *sex roles* itself is [being argued about in the scientific literature](https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C43&q=On+anisogamy+and+the+evolution+of+%E2%80%98sex+roles%E2%80%99&btnG=&oq=on+anisogamy). 
We want students to understand that there is a general pattern of how male and female animals tend to behave, but these are not actually prescriptive *roles* and there is a great deal of variation within and across species.
steps.Vocab:
- **sex roles:** in nonhuman animals, behaviors and attributes that typically apply to one sex or the other
- **conventional sex roles:** "caring females" and "competitive males"; the pattern in most animal species wherein females contribute more to ensure the survival of offspring, while males spend more effort toward attracting and competing for mates
- **sex-role-reversal:** "caring males" and "competitive females"; this is a less common pattern among animals, in which males contribute more to parental care and females compete for access to mates
steps.TeachingTips: Make sure to emphasize that we're *not talking about humans*. Later, we will also draw the distinctions between gender and sex.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Let students share a bit of their knowledge and perhaps begin to disagree about classifications. We want them to start thinking about how complex and variable animal mating systems are.

steps.StepTitle: Across animals, is one sex more involved in *caring* for young, while the other is focused on *competing* for mates?
steps.StepQuickDescription: Set up our driving question and define the language we'll be using.
steps.Vocab:
sex: a category (male or female) determined by which gametes an individual produces (i.e. eggs for females and sperm for males)
- **gender:** a complex social category based on how an individual identifies (e.g. male, female, nonbinary)
steps.TeachingTips: We always use *sex*, rather than *gender* to refer to nonhuman animals, since we can't ask animals how they identify. However, there is some [very interesting ongoing research looking into animal genders](https://www.discovermagazine.com/planet-earth/is-gender-identity-unique-to-humans).

steps.StepQuickDescription: A card-based simulated data collection activity involving "song" and dance
steps.StepDetails:
Students each get *at least* 1 card from the [♧'"Role With It" Cards'](https://drive.google.com/file/d/18YviuSZR_uxPaOwFUGLyERjwl1P_fNz2/view?usp=sharing). This card is their "specimen" (male or female of a  species), which they will introduce to the class as they collect its data. Each card has provided sexual signal values (from 0 to 3) for visual and acoustic (sound) traits. Zero means a specimen doesn't have that type of signal; 3 means that sex of that species has a very exaggerated trait. Students will build a dataset of relative sexual signal elaboration (e.g. how fancy the feathers and songs are) and parental investment for each sex across 12 different species.
The presentation guides the game. When a specimen's common name is called, the student with that card must stand up and introduce it. They will repeat their name 3-5 times at a volume corresponding to the Acoustic Signal Score on their card. Simultaneously, they will do a dance that is at the level of the Visual Display Score on their card. 
After the introduction, the student will read for their classmates the Parental Investment information on the card. Everyone then records display scores and parental contributions, which they will use for futher analysis. Then the next card is introduced.
steps.Vocab:
- **signals:** traits evolved to communicate something to a receiver (e.g. "danger," "I'm here," or "mine")
- **sexual signals:** traits evolved specifically to communicate in the context of mate attraction, competition, or both
- **visual signals:** traits evolved to communicate by sight (e.g. feather shapes and colors; antlers; or bright patches of skin)
- **acoustic signals:** traits evolved to communicate through sound (e.g. bird and whale song; cricket chirps; or frog calls)
steps.TeachingTips:
We've included 30sec timers in the presentation to keep things moving along, as students will find much of the goings on *quite* entertaining.
It's a good idea to demonstrate the "song" and dances, and set rules for what a "3" means in terms of movement and volume. One of us demoed a floss and while one student "died of cringe," another confided that it made her day. Have fun! :)

steps.StepTitle: Pass out cards and let students trade
steps.StepDetails: Each student should have at least 1 card. In small classes, students may have several. In a large class (>24), you will need to have more than 1 deck to allow each student to have a card. If you have multiple students introducing a specimen, you should call on one to read the *Parental Contributions* section.
steps.TeachingTips: Once they have the data, Part 2 can be done independently for homework or during another class period.

steps.StepTitle: Students will make 24 small performances as they introduce their species, followed by data collection.
steps.StepQuickDescription: This will be somewhat of a chaotic lesson, but students should definitely find it engaging. They will enjoy performing and seeing their classmates perform.
steps.StepDetails: Everything downstream requires that all students collect the data they are introducing. Students will likely need periodic reminders to focus and take down the data to move on. We've added the timers as a reminder.
steps.Vocab:
- **dewlap:** the extendable flap under some lizards (such as the green anole), which is used for competition and mate attraction
- **wattle:** a fleshy flap of skin on some birds (such as turkeys and jacanas) that likely plays a role in mate choice
steps.TeachingTips: We include short videos after some of the species have been introduced to show students their actual display behaviors. Make sure you have the sound on! :loud_sound:

steps.StepTitle: Collect work to finish later in class or assign homework
steps.StepQuickDescription: If you finished, have students make sure they've totaled all their scores in Table 1.
steps.StepDetails: If you don't quite get through the P1 Presentation, simply collect student papers (you can have them place cards on top of their worksheet packet and stack them). They should have recorded which cards they had on Q1-5, as well, so it's straightforward to pick up where you left off on data collection at the last species in Table 1 on the worksheet.
steps.TeachingTips: Once they have the data, the rest can be done independently for homework or during another class period, depending how you'd like to support your students.

parts.partPreface: Students organize, analyze, and interpret the data they collected in Part 1. They will define the pattern of *conventional sex roles* from the data  (most species have "caring females" and "competitive males"), and identify exceptional species that buck the trend.

steps.StepTitle: Transferring raw data to a summary table
steps.StepQuickDescription: What do the data say about our question: **Across animals, is one sex more involved in *caring* for young, while the other is focused on *competing* for mates?**
steps.StepDetails: Students will copy their Total Sexual Signaling Scores and Total Parental Investment Scores from Table 1 to Table 2. They will then right the correct symbol (<, >, or =), according to how male and female scores compare to each other.
steps.VariantNotes: There is no presentation for Part 2. The worksheet should guide students in analysis of their data.
steps.TeachingTips: You may want to have students work in pairs on this part in order to help them troubleshoot and spot each other's mistakes.

steps.StepQuickDescription: In order to make your life easier, and introduce students to an important computer science concept, we've implemented a checksum for Table 2.
steps.StepDetails: After reorganizing their raw data in Table 2, students should add up each category of scores to get totals. Students will know if their data is valid (correct) if the column totals equal the expected *checksums.* If not, they should work with a classmate to find the error before coming to you to troubleshoot.
steps.Vocab: - **checksum:** in computer science, this is a value used to determine if data are valid. If a calculation does not result in the expected checksum, it is a sign that something went wrong. (e.g. checksums are used to determine if you've put in a [valid credit card number](https://www.sapling.com/7966257/checksum-credit-card))

steps.StepQuickDescription: The worksheet guides students through a basic summary analysis and reflection on the data.
steps.StepDetails:
What students should gain from this exercise:
- recognize that there is a lot of variation in nature
- a general recognition that when one sex contributes significantly more parental investment, it frees the other sex to evolve adaptations to compete for mates
- they should independently conclude that the majority of species have "caring females" and "competitive males" (*conventional sex roles*), while recognizing that there are many cases where both parents contribute equivalently, and some species with *sex role reversal*.

parts.partPreface: Students use real data collected from the field in Borneo to test whether Guardian Frogs are the first known amphibian with sex role reversal (caring males and competitive females).

background.Content:
#### Connection to Research
 Instead of telling students, "In animal species with *conventional sex roles,* males invest more in attracting and competing for mates, while females invest more in parental care," we have students collect data in a fun, interactive format and draw this conclusion from the data. They are then more invested in understanding cases of *sex role reversed species* that are the exceptions to this role, and have "caring males" and "competitive females." In part 2, they dive into the hypothesis-based framework and follow along in the footsteps of an early career Latina scientist, Dr. Johana Goyes-Vallejos. They analyze real graphs and data she collected on the island of Borneo to determine if the Smooth Guardian Frog (*Limnonectes palavanensis*) is the first sex-role-reversed frog species known to science.

learning-chart.Title: About the GP Learning Chart
learning-chart.Description:
This Galactic Polymath Learning Chart illustrates the areas of knowledge covered. This lesson targets Science, but it helps teach national learning standards in 4 subjects: 
- [Common Core Math](http://www.corestandards.org/Math/); [Common Core ELA](http://www.corestandards.org/ELA-Literacy/); [Next Generation Science (NGSS)](https://www.nextgenscience.org/); and [College, Career, and Civic Life (C3) Social Studies Standards](https://www.socialstudies.org/standards/c3).
In total, there are 15 standards across US grade band(s): 5-6, 7-8.
learning-chart.Footnote:
**Notes on Standards**

*Standards are broken down into ***Target*** and ***Connected*** categories. Target standards are directly reinforced or taught; connected standards are not fully addressed in the lesson, but connected enough to provide a foundation for teachers to build upon.

standardsGroup.statements: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will graph data, and become familiar with plotting the center and spread with boxplots, using real data on Guardian Frog behavior.

standardsGroup.statements: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will practice graphing real biological data that is variable, and in so doing, will gain experience displaying numerical data in plots on a number scale, such as box plots.

standardsGroup.statements: Interpret information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and explain how it contributes to a topic, text, or issue under study.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will be presented with data visualizations, including graphs, along with oral and textual scientific information, and will be asked to interpret this information to understand the relationship between animal behavior and sexual selection.

standardsGroup.statements: Integrate visual information (e.g., in charts, graphs, photographs, videos, or maps) with other information in print and digital texts.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will integrate their findings from data visualization in graphs along with a piece of scientific text on Exceptions in Nature.

standardsGroup.statements: Determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary of the source distinct from prior knowledge or opinions.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will read a secondary source on Exceptions in Biology, from which we will ask them to draw on specific citations in their discussion of why exceptions in biology matter, and how they relate both specifically to our discussion of Guardian Frogs, and more broadly to the field of biology and beyond.

standardsGroup.statements: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for phenomena.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will plot real biological data in boxplots and interpret their data visualization to provide evidence to test their hypotheses about sex role reversal.

standardsGroup.statements: Ask questions that arise from careful observation of phenomena, models, or unexpected results, to clarify and/or seek additional information.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will practice looking at real data that is variable, and become familiar with looking at mean and variability, through experience plotting boxplots and follow-up interpretation of data and discussion.

standardsGroup.statements: Apply concepts of statistics and probability (including mean, median, mode, and variability) to analyze and characterize data, using digital tools when feasible.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will practice looking at real data that is variable, and become familiar with looking at mean and variability, through experience plotting boxplots and follow-up interpretation of data and discussion.

standardsGroup.statements: Critically read scientific texts adapted for classroom use to determine the central ideas and/or obtain scientific and/or technical information to describe patterns in and/or evidence about the natural and designed world(s).
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will read a scientific text on Exceptions in Biology, which they will summarize and interact with to understand why exceptions to the rule matter in biological systems.

standardsGroup.statements: Patterns can be used to identify cause-and-effect relationships.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will plot real biological data in boxplots and interpret their data visualization to provide evidence to test their hypotheses about sex role reversal.

standardsGroup.statements: Biodiversity describes the variety of species found in Earth’s terrestrial and oceanic ecosystems. The completeness or integrity of an ecosystem’s biodiversity is often used as a measure of its health.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - As an extension, students may investigate the relationship between biodiversity and geography, learning the definition of biodiversity and how habitat destruction and fragmentation can impact biodiversity, as is the case with the Guardian Frogs of Borneo.

standardsGroup.statements: Use maps, satellite images, photographs, and other representations to explain relationships between the locations of places and regions, and changes in their environmental characteristics.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will investigate a map of Borneo that overlays environmental characteristics, from which they can make interpretations about the relationship between geography and biodiversity, and how these might be impacted by habitat loss.

standardsGroup.statements: Animals engage in characteristic behaviors that increase the odds of reproduction.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will discuss why animals reproduce, and what types of behavior animals engage in to increase the odds of reproduction, and, after an overview of typical behavior, we will discuss examples of exceptions to the rule, such as sex role reversal.

standardsGroup.statements: Apply scientific ideas, principles, and/or evidence to construct, revise and/or use an explanation for real-world phenomena, examples, or events.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will integrate data visualization of real biological data and scientific text, using scientific ideas and principles to investigate an real example of exceptions to the rule in nature, with evidence for sex role reversal in Guardian Frogs.

standardsGroup.statements: Graphs, charts, and images can be used to identify patterns in data.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will practice looking at real data that is variable, and become familiar with looking at mean and variability, through experience plotting boxplots and follow-up interpretation of data and discussion.
